captions.text:
We’re surrounded by it every winter, but
how much do you really know about snow?

It falls out of the sky, we shovel it off
the sidewalk, we ski on it, sled on it, make

snowballs with it - but do you ever stop to
think about what makes snow? I do! Cuz it’s
my job.

Snow is made of a few basic ingredients: air,
water and a tiny bit of dust, volcanic ash,

mica or even particles from space that made
it through that atmosphere. As the temperature

drops, 180 billion molecules of water condense
around the dust particles and freezes into

an ice crystal; the colder the temperature
the sharper their points will be.[a] These

crystals eventually clump, forming a snowflake.
What you see falling isn't a single crystal,

but these massive clumps. Though, a single
flake can grow quite large -- like, inches

wide -- and contain hundreds of individual
paper-thin crystals.

All snowflakes have six sides, always six…
which means contrary to popular belief, they're

not all different or unique, in fact, they
form a crystalline pattern and crystals follow

specific rules, so they're all very similar.
Snowflakes fall at 3.1 mph (5 kph) and as

they do, the temperature, humidity and wind
speed will all affect the flake's consistency.

The crystalline structures of snow are NOT
white, but translucent and colorless, just

like ice., They only appear white because
they scatter all wavelengths of light equally.

However, sometimes what's in the air can change
the color of snow. Pollen, dust, ash or other

particles that the flakes pickup as they call
can make it look yellow, red or even black.

As much as 95 percent of the snowflake is
made of air, trapped in-between the crystal's

arms and filaments. Once it snows enough,
all that air in the snowflakes will begin

to absorb sound, which is why snowy nights
feel sooooo silent…..

Additionally, once the snow starts to pile
up, the air in between the flakes makes for

a very good insulator. Which is why igloos
and caves of snow are really quite warming.

Of course, lifting all that snow to make a
cave could get heavy, so dress in layers.

The fattest flakes only weigh 0.02 grams,
so for a pound of snow, you'd need 22,325

flakes. To put that in perspective a light
snowfall can result in between 10-20 snowflakes
per second for every square meter of ground.

If you get enough snow, and it get heavy…
avalanches happen. When enormous amounts of

snow piles up on a mountain with a 30-degree
or steeper grade, things get crazy. The weight

becomes too much for those tiny crystals to
hold onto one another and eventually gravity

pulls a sheet of the snow together, shearing
it off the main body and here comes an avalanche!

Due to snow's ability to melt and re-freeze,
the layers of a mountain snowfall make layers

just like sedimentary rock, which is why avalanches
are very unpredictable. Shout all you want,
loud sounds don't cause avalanches.

I know, I know, the question on everyone’s
mind every winter is how do you make the perfect

snowball? Wait til it's 32 degrees (0C) and
use snow with a bit of moisture. Melting it

in your hands will make it pack better. Your
hands will hurt after a while and if you do

it for too long, so be careful… That sustained
cold temperature could permanently damage

your skin, but if you can last for a short
burst; the tiny crystals will stick together
just right. Just pick your target wisely…

If you liked this and learned something, share
it with a friend!

Tell us about your experience with snow down
in the comments and subscribe for more DNews.

title: 13 Things You Didn’t Know About Snow
